Topic.Title: Better than Yelp, Angi, Zillow, Open Table or MeetMe - All Yahoo should not buy

Message.Msg: Angies List is extreme overvalued and Local Corp extreme undervalued, if you take a look at the following compare Business Outlook of Angies List which has a market-cap of 1,150 million: The Company's financial and operating expectations for the first quarter of 2013 are as follows: Total revenue in the range of $51.0 million to $52.0 million for the first quarter of 2013. Marketing expense in the range of $19.0 million to $20.0 million for the first quarter of 2013. Fiscal 2013 Financial Guidance of Local Corp with 35 million market cap: Revenue - The company expects 2013 revenue of between $93 million and $95 million, which at the mid-point, is an increase of 12 percent, over the fourth quarter 2012 exit run rate. Adjusted Net Income â€“ Adjusted Net Income for 2013 is expected to be at least $5 million, which would result in approximately $1 million in debt-free cash flow. The company defines debt-free cash flow as cash provided by operating activities, less capital expenditures. Angies List has with about 215 million revenues in 2013 against the 94 million of Local Corp only the 2.3-fold revenues, but with 1,150 million market-cap against the idiotic low 35 million of Local Corp the 33-fold market-cap.

Message.Title: Progress of Yahoo's stock buyback
Message.Msg: After repurchasing $1.5 billion of stock in the fourth quarter (30% more than the prior twelve months combined), Yahoo is still on the buyback bandwagon in the first quarter. According to a footnote (page 112) in Yahooâ€™s annual securities filing, the company bought back another $663 million worth of shares in January and February at an average price of $20.23. That brings the total to $2.1 billion since October (average price: $18.78). And thereâ€™s likely more to come. Yahoo had $6 billion of cash and securities on its balance sheet at the end of 2012. Even after the first quarterâ€™s repurchases, dry powder is still well above $5 billion. The company was authorized to repurchase an additional $3.4 billion worth of shares at the end of the year.

Message.Title: yahoo has original programming - looks like it is becoming more valuable every day
Message.Msg: And content creation is where Netflix is hoping to stave off the margin erosion that has been dogging the stock. Its new series "House of Cards" debuted on 1st February. The new incarnation of cult classic "Arrested Development" is set to debut in May - releasing all 14 episodes at once like it has done previously. The plan is simple -- moving from exclusive content to original programming. This is where the competition in the future will be. This was laid down clearly by the company's executives when they said that in the long run, the businesses (Netflix, HBO Go, Redbox, etc.) will be competing "more like [how] Showtime and HBO do today," The cable giants are hampered by their status with the FCC, whereas Netflix, and others like Hulu and Amazon (AMZN) are not. It came as zero shock to me that Amazon, for example, will be getting into original programming after playing catch up with its Prime video service by breaking down Netflix's exclusivity with Epix.

Topic.Title: Progress of Yahoo's stock buyback

Message.Msg: What is the difference between a company with 300M shares, $5EPS vs. a company with 1.5B shares and $1EPS? All the financial engineering in the world isn't going to change the fact the company is still worth the SAME Its only ignoring the fact it needs to be invested in the core. Multiple expansion on a rapidly expanding core looks better than a company who only buy shares at which point the multiple will collapse. As for Bravo's assertion they make $2B, that isn't remotely accurate. Last year, the core made $850M and another $650M came from INVESTMENTS. Last quarter, operating income fell 30% if I remember right. IF they cash out both Yahoo Japan and AG, those earnings will fall. 50-.60. IF they start their own search engine again with $1B opex then earnings will be FLAT or NEGATIVE(doubt they're that dumb). To compensate for that 1/3rd fall in earnings they'd have to buyback 1/3rd the shares. As for tech companies offering dividends...MATURE tech companies do as does Cisco, Intel, Microsoft and even Apple. My only point is Yahoo core needs fixing and buying shares or giving dividends ain't it. GL(was tempted to go long this morning when it was flat and market negative so see how it plays out tomorrow)

Topic.Title: Progress of Yahoo's stock buyback

Message.Msg: Just to clarify, I don't suggest paying dividends fixes Yahoo it just may 1) inspire some business discipline and 2) move some of the cash back to long suffering equity holders. Oh, and BTW, my point is that while "maturing" Yahoo stopped being a tech company (goods and services) and became a media (we sell ads) company.
